Graphical abstract Ru0.2-Co3O4 shows much higher activity than the Co3O4 catalyst at same temperature and has better stability and resistance towards H2O compared with Co3O4 catalyst. A serial of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1, 0.2 and 0.3) catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method and applied to the decomposition of N2O. They were characterized by the XRD, TEM, Raman, H2-TPR, XPS, O2-TPD and in situ DRIFTS. The results indicate that the strong interaction between Co and Ru exists in the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, which results in much larger BET surface area, better structural stability and more surface Co2+, Ru3+ and oxygen species compared with Co3O4. Additionally, the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, especial Ru0.2-Co3O4, show much higher activity and stability than the Co3O4 catalyst due to the synergistic effect of Ru and Co3O4. Moreover, the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst shows much stronger resistance against 2.1% H2O and 1.5% O2 in the feed than Co3O4. Keywords Interaction N2O decomposition Co3O4 Ru 1 Introduction N2O is a major pollutant to destroy ozone in the stratosphere. Because of its long lifetime (110–150 years), N2O becomes a strong greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, whose greenhouse potential is 310 times higher than that of CO2 [1–3]. In recent years, the growth rate of atmospheric concentration of N2O is about 0.5 to 1.0 ppbv each year [4]. N2O mainly derives from the production of chemical factories such as the synthesis of adipic acid and nitric acid, the burning of fossil fuels and biomass [4]. Therefore, it is necessary to control N2O emissions from combustion and chemical processes. The catalytic decomposition of N2O into N2 and O2 is considered as a very effective method [5]. In scientific researches, several catalysts including noble metals (Rh, Pd, Ru, Ir, Pt), non-noble metals (Fe, Mn, Cu, Co, Ni) and composite oxides such as perovskites, spinels, hexaaluminates oxides and mixed oxides obtained by calcination of hydrotalcites have been explored in terms of N2O decomposition [6–19]. For metals, it was found that their activities order was as followed: Ru, Rh, Ir>Pd>Cu>Fe>Pt>Ni>Mn [18,20]. Ru was regarded as an efficient active component for catalytic N2O decomposition [13,21]. But the activity of Ru-based catalyst strongly depended on the dispersion, stabilization and the surface species of Ru [11,16]. In our previous study [10], the instability and agglomeration of Ru particles resulted in the decrease of the catalytic activity even deactivation for N2O decomposition. In addition, H2O presented a negative effect on the decomposition of N2O over Ru catalyst [19]. Thus, how to improve the stabilization and H2O resistance is an important factor for Ru catalysts. Co3O4 was also identified as one of the highly active catalysts for N2O decomposition [22–27]. But the deactivation phenomenon usually occurred for Co3O4 [9,26,28,29]. In past years, researchers have found the introduction of K, Cu, Ce and Pb into the Co3O4 spinel could make up its deficiency [30–34]. The K doping Co3O4 could increase the activities for the decomposition of N2O due to the interaction between K and Co3O4 leading to the increase in the number of active sites and the promotion of oxygen desorption. And the unsaturated Co2+ species were stabilized by the electron donating effect of highly basic oxygen influenced by K+ ions [32,33]. The introduction of Pb in Co3O4 could weaken the Co-O bond and decrease the average size of crystallites which can increase the surface area and active sites for the Pb0.04Co catalyst [31]. What’s more, the addition of CeO2 can promote the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ by facilitating the desorption of adsorbed oxygen species and greatly increase the surface area of catalyst [34]. The presence of Cu2+ enhanced the thermal reduction of Co3+ ions, forming Co2+ ions, which are essential for initiating the reaction [30]. In general, the surface and bulk properties of the Co3O4 catalyst can be modified after addition of metal, e.g. surface area, desorption of adsorbed oxygen species, reducibility, number of active sites etc. In our previous work [14], it has also been found that Co3O4 showed quick deactivation for N2O decomposition regardless of whether there is water or not. Therefore, CoxTi catalysts were prepared which exhibited high stability and resistance against H2O, nevertheless, they showed lower catalytic activity than that of Co3O4 [14]. Though some literatures reported Co3O4 based catalysts displayed high activity and stability for N2O decomposition, however, most of them were sensitive to the presence of H2O very much [33,34]. Hence, the development of a suitable Co3O4-based catalyst with high activity, stability and H2O resistance for N2O decomposition is still a key issue in the environmental catalysis field. According to the above descriptions, we have put forward to prepare Rux-Co3O4 to enhance the catalytic activity, stability and resistance towards H2O. Here, a serial of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1, 0.2 and 0.3) catalysts with 0.1%, 0.2% and 0.3% Ru weight were synthesized by coprecipitation method and tested for decomposition of N2O. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Rux-Co3O4 mixed oxide catalysts with mass percentage of 0.1%, 0.2% and 0.3% Ru were prepared by coprecipitation method [30]. Briefly, stoichiometric RuCl3 solution (2, 4 and 6mL, 5.00mmolL−1) and Co(NO3)3·6H2O (3.62g) were mixed and dissolved in 100mL deionized water. After stirring 30min, an aqueous solution of Na2CO3 (2.00molL−1) was added drop-wise into the solution under stirring till a pH of 9.3 was reached at room temperature. The slurry was stirred for 30min and aged for 3h at room temperature. The mixture was filtered and precipitate was washed with deionized water till no chloride ion tested by the mixture of AgNO3 and HNO3. Subsequently, the obtained precipitate was dried at 100°C overnight. A series of sample were calcined in air at 500°C for 3h. The catalysts were denoted as Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1, 0.2 and 0.3), where x represents the nominal Ru percentage content of catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded via a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer, using Cu Kα (λ =1.5418Å) radiation (40kV, 40mA). The 2θ scans cover the range of 20–80° with the steps of 0.02°.The BET surface area was measured with the BET method by the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at −196°C using a Micromeritics Tristar 3020 analyzer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements were taken on a JEM-2100 electron microscope operating at 200kV. The elemental mapping images of EDX analysis were recorded by FeiNa phenom prox electron microscope operating. Raman spectra were recorded with a Jobin Yvon HR 800 micro-Raman spectrometer at 457.9nm. The XPS measurements were performed on an AXIS ULTRA DLD X spectrometer using Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. Binding energy (BE) was referred to the C (1s) binding energy of carbon taken to be 284.7eV. In addition to a survey spectrum, detailed scans of O(1s), Ru(3d), C(1s) and Co(3p) regions were acquired for each sample. The reducibility of the catalysts was studied by temperature programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) using an AutoChem tp5080 (Xianquan) chemisorption analyzer. In a typical experiment, the sample (0.020g) was pretreated in flowing N2 (30mLmin−1) for 1h at 300°C, then cooled to room temperature. The temperature was increased to 400°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a 10% H2/N2 flow (30mLmin−1). Temperature programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) experiments were tested by using the AutoChem tp5080 chemisorptions analyzer. For each experiment, the catalyst (0.100g) was pretreated in flowing O2 (30mLmin−1) for 1h at 300°C, then cooled to room temperature. The temperature was increased to 600°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in He flow (30mLmin−1). In situ DRIFTS was recorded with a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with in situ diffuse reflectance pool (Harrick) and high sensitivity MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. The catalyst was loaded in the diffuse reflectance pool and heated to 300°C (N2: 40mLmin−1, 60min) and then cooled to 50°C. The background spectrum was collected in flowing N2 atmosphere and subtracted from the sample spectra. The spectra were collected in the presence of gas CO (20mLmin−1) at 50°C. The DRIFTS was recorded by accumulating 64 scans with a resolution of 4cm−1 and presented without smoothing. The total flow rate was about 40mLmin−1. 2.3 Catalytic experiments N2O decomposition was tested with a fixed-bed quartz-glass 6 mm-internal diameter tubular reactor. Gaseous mixtures (5000ppmN2O with He) were fed to the catalyst bed in a flow rate of 25mLmin−1. In each experiment, the catalyst (0.100g, 40–60mesh) was placed in the reactor of quartz wool. At each examined temperature, the reaction was remained for 60min before measuring in a temperature range of 200–425°C. In addition, the time-on-stream at 400 and 500°C was tested: 500ppmN2O in He; the total flow rate of the feed was 200mLmin−1 and the catalyst weight was 0.100g (GHSV h−1). The H2O, O2 resistance was tested at 400°C in below conditions: 500ppmN2O, 2.1vol% H2O or 1.5vol% O2 in He; the total flow rate of 200mLmin−1 and 0.100g catalyst (GHSV of h−1). The concentration measurements of reaction products and the remaining N2O at the reactor outlet were performed by gas chromatography (SP3420A, Beifen, China) equipped with 5A molecular sieves and Porabond Q columns. The conversion of N2O decomposition was calculated by the following equations: (1) C o n v . = ( [ N 2 O ] i n − [ N 2 O ] o u t ) [ N 2 O ] i n × 100 % Conv. is the N2O conversion, [N2O]in is N2O concentration before the reaction, [N2O]out is the N2O concentration after the reaction. Specific reaction rate (r), rate constant (k) and activation energy (E a) were calculated according to the following Eqs. (2)–(4), respectively [31]: (2) r = p 0 × F × 5000 × 10 − 6 R × T 0 × m cat × conv. ( μ mol s − 1 g cat − 1 ) (3) k = r c (4) I n k = I n A − E a RT p 0 is atmospheric pressure (101 KPa), F (mLs−1) is the total flow rate of feed gas mixture, R is gas constant (8.314JK−1 mol−1), mcat is the amount of the catalyst, T 0 is the room temperature (298K), c (μmolm−3) is the N2O concentrations from the outlet of the reactor, T (K) is reaction temperature [31]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of XRD and surface area Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts. The diffraction peaks for Co3O4 appeared at 31.3°, 37°, 44.9°, 59.4° and 65.4° corresponding to (220), (311), (400), (511) and (440) planes of the Co3O4 spinel structure (JCPDS 43–1003), respectively [14,30]. The XRD patterns of Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4 catalysts exhibited almost the same lines as Co3O4, and no diffraction peaks assigned to metallic Ru and RuOx species could be identified, which indicates ruthenium may be highly dispersed in the catalysts. For the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, the diffraction intensities were much weaker than that of pure Co3O4, which suggests that the crystallite size and crystallinity decrease compared with pure Co3O4. As listed in Table 1 , the average particle dimension (D) of the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts was about 14.7–27.4nm. It is observed that particle dimension of Co3O4 in Rux-Co3O4 is smaller than that of the pure Co3O4 (28nm), especially, Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst showed the smallest average crystallite dimension (14.7nm). It is speculated that the interaction exists between Co and Ru in the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts. The data of BET surface areas (SBET) for the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts are displayed in Table 1. The SBET of Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4 catalysts was 9.4, 21.7 and 13.8m2 g−1, respectively, which were obviously higher than that of the Co3O4 (5.5m2 g−1). The introduction of Ru into Co3O4 resulted in an increase in its SBET values. It can be attributed to the decrease in crystallite size and the surface reconstruction derived from the interaction between Ru and Co. In the literatures [14,31,35,36], it was also found that the SBET of Co3O4 increased after the addition of metal. For example, the BET surface area was 64.7, 51, 22.5 and 15.3m2 g−1 for the doping Pb [31], Ti [14], Zn [35] and Bi [36] in Co3O4 catalysts, respectively. 3.2 TEM analysis TEM images were measured to investigate the particle size of Co3O4 and Ru0.2-Co3O4. As shown in Fig. 2 , it was clear that Co3O4 particles could be observed in the Co3O4 (Fig. 2a) and Ru0.2-Co3O4 (Fig. 2e) samples. And the HRTEM image showed that the lattice distances are about 0.243, 0.286 and 0.479nm, which are assigned to the (311), (220) and (111) lattice plane of Co3O4. The average particle size was analyzed by calculating at least 100 individual particles in Fig. 2a, e and S1 (Supplementary information). It can be seen that the percentage of the particle size in the Co3O4 whose average size is 29.2nm in the ranged from 10 to 30nm was about 57% (Fig. 2d), while it increased to 83% in the Ru0.2-Co3O4 with the average size of 18.2nm (Fig. 2l). It suggests that the particle sizes of Co3O4 decrease after adding Ru into Co3O4, which is consistent with the XRD results. In addition, Ru particles could not be found in Ru0.2-Co3O4 (Fig. 2e), which is ascribed to the lower amount of Ru (0.2%) and the less particle size of Ru species. Moreover, the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst was studied by means of elemental mapping images of SEM-EDX analysis. The mapping results in the zone of Fig. 2i are shown in Fig. 2j and k. It can be found that the distribution of Co and Ru are same. This indicates that Ru element is well dispersed in the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst. 3.3 Raman spectra Fig. S2 (Supplementary information) shows the Raman spectra of the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts. It can be seen that five Raman peaks appeared at 193, 478, 518, 617 and 678cm−1 for Rux-Co3O4 and Co3O4, which were assigned to the 3×F2g, Eg and A1g vibrational modes of Co3O4, respectively [37]. In addition, in terms of the change of Raman peaks for Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3), the half peak width of F2g vibration at 193cm−1 and A1g vibration at 678cm−1 was measured, as shown in Table 1. It can be seen that the Raman peaks for Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts did not shift compared with Co3O4, which suggests the structure of Co3O4 was not destroyed due to the small amount of Ru. However, It was found that the half peak width of F2g vibration at 193cm−1 was 11.8, 13.0 and 15.0cm−1, A1g vibration at 678cm−1 was 22.0, 23.9 and 39.2cm−1 for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively, which were larger than that of Co3O4 (11.3 and 20.9cm−1). The half peak width increased with the x of Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, which also suggests the presence of the interaction between Co and Ru in the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts. 3.4 Results of H2-TPR and O2-TPD The H2-TPR of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts was measured to examine the reducibility, as shown in Fig. 3 . The Co3O4 showed two hydrogen consumption peaks between 200 and 400°C, which were ascribed to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ at 280°C and the subsequent reduction of Co2+ to the metallic cobalt (Co0) at 350°C [34,38]. For Rux-Co3O4, two reduction peaks at 200–300 and 300–375°C were observed. The first peak was assigned to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ (mainly) and the relatively small amounts of the Ru4+ and Ru3+ species [19]. The second high temperature peak was attributed to Co2+ to Co0. It can be seen that the reduction peaks for the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts shifted to the low temperature compared with Co3O4. Moreover, the reduction peak temperature decreased with increasing x value in the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts, which should be attributed to two aspects reasons. One is the decrease of crystallite size that is favor of the reduction of metal oxides [39], and another is that the Co-O bond becomes more easily broken after Ru doping [31]. These results can assigned to the influence of Ru addition on the property of Co3O4. Fig. 4 presents the O2-TPD profiles of the Co3O4 and Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts. It was noticed that there were two desorption peaks from 100°C to 550°C for the Co3O4 and Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts. The first peak at 100–250°C was ascribed to the desorption of the chemisorbed oxygen on the surface oxygen vacancy (Vo) [24]. It was noticed that the peak area of the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts was larger than that of Co3O4. Meanwhile, the desorption of the surface chemisorbed oxygen for Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) showed much lower temperature compared with Co3O4. In particular, Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst had the largest value of peak area and the lowest temperature of desorption. This suggests that the amount and desorption ability of the surface chemisorbed oxygen increased for the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts, which can be due to the change of the surface structure derived from the strong interaction between Co and Ru. The second reduction peak located between 300 and 550°C for Co3O4 and Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) was mainly assigned to the desorption of surface lattice oxygen [40]. The desorption peaks at 405, 456 and 417°C for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively, shifted to the higher temperature compared with the Co3O4 (384°C). The highest temperature of surface lattice oxygen desorption was observed for the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst (456°C). It means that the surface lattice oxygen of the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts desorbed more difficultly than that of Co3O4. It indicates that the surface structural stability of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts increased after adding Ru into Co3O4, which was derived from the interaction of the Co and Ru. 3.5 XPS analysis The XPS of Co2p, Ru3d and O1s were acquired for the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts in order to study the surface species. The XPS of Co 2p3/2 is shown in Fig. 5 a. The peaks at 780.6 and 779.1eV were attributed to the Co2+ and Co3+, respectively [41,42]. Additionally, the shake-up satellite peak located at 786.5eV was also detected, suggesting the presence of Co2+ species [43]. It was noteworthy that the Co 2p3/2 peaks of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1, 0.2) shifted to the lower binding energy than that of Co3O4. The literatures have also reported the same results in the XPS of K/Co3O4 [32,33] and Cu0.2Ce0.8Oy [44]. This suggests that the binding energy change may be due to the electron donation toward cobalt [33]. The ratio of Co2+ to Co3+ (Co2+/Co3+) was calculated from the fitting areas of Co 2p3/2 listed in Table 1. The Co2+/Co3+ was about 1.00 on the surface of Co3O4 catalyst, whereas it was about 1.45, 1.59 and 1.45 for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively (Table 1). It demonstrates that the amount of Co2+ increases on the surface of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts. Among the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts, Ru0.2-Co3O4 possesses the largest atomic concentration of Co2+ on its surface. Fig. 5b presents the XPS of Ru3d obtained from the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts, and the peak fitting was carried out. The 3d5/2 peaks at 282.3 and 283.3eV were assigned to the Ru3+ and Ru4+ species, respectively, and corresponding the binding energies of 3d3/2 were at 286.3 (Ru3+) and 287.9eV (Ru4+) [45,46]. The ratio of Ru3+ to Ru4+ (Ru3+/Ru4+) was calculated from the peak area of Ru3d envelope listed in Table 1. It was found that the relative amounts of Ru3+ was different for Rux-Co3O4. The Ru3+/Ru4+ ratio was about 1.86, 2.57 and 1.44 for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively (Table 1). Among the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3), the largest amount of Ru3+ exists on the surface of Ru0.2-Co3O4. Fig. 5c depicts the O1s spectra of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts. In the XPS of O1s, the peaks located at about 532.3–533.1, 530.9–531.7 and 529.5–530.0eV were obtained. The BE at 529.5–530.0eV was attributed to the surface lattice oxygen (Oβ) [47–49]; the BE at 530.9–531.7eV was ascribed to the surface oxygen species (Oα1) adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy [47–49] and the BE at 532.3-533.1eV could be assigned to the adsorbed oxygen from hydroxyl or water species (Oα2) on the surface [47,50]. The O1s peaks of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) shifted to the lower BE than that of Co3O4, which could due to the contribution of the oxygen from RuO2. In the literatures, the decrease in the BE of O1s for Co3O4 after the addition of CeO2 was considered as the relation to the oxygen from CeO2 [51,52]. Furthermore, the ratio of Oα1 to total oxygen species (Oα1/(Oα1 +Oα2 +Oβ)) was calculated and showed in Table 1. It was noticed that the Oα1/(Oα1 +Oα2 +Oβ) was 0.44, 0.50 and 0.44 for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively, which was higher than that of Co3O4 (0.38) (Table 1). It reveals that the surface oxygen adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy increases on the surface of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts. To further understand the surface property, the adsorption of CO as probe was studied by in situ DRIFTS for Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Co3O4. As displayed in Fig. S3 (Supplementary information), two bands were found at 2172 and 2111cm−1. It belonged to the adsorbed CO [53]. The spectra of CO adsorption over the Co3O4 and Ru0.2-Co3O4 showed the same bands at 1000–1700cm−1 which was attributed to mono-, bi- and polydentate carbonates, bicarbonate and formate species [54]. It can be seen that the adsorption species on the surface of Co3O4 and Ru0.2-Co3O4 was the same as each other. However, the relative intensity of bands at 1000–1700cm−1 of Ru0.2-Co3O4 was much higher than that of the Co3O4, which indicates that the adsorption amount of CO is much higher for Ru0.2-Co3O4. Among those adsorption bands, the band appearing at 1636cm−1 was assigned to the CO adsorption on Co2+ [31]. Therefore, the amount of Co2+ on the surface of Ru0.2-Co3O4 should also be much higher than that of Co3O4. This result is consistent with the XPS of Co2p. 3.6 Catalytic activity evalution Fig. 6 presents the N2O conversion at different reaction temperature over the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) and Co3O4 catalysts in direct N2O decomposition. As shown in Fig. 6, N2O conversion was about 10%, 40% and 70% at 300, 350 and 375°C over the Co3O4 catalyst, respectively. The Rux-Co3O4 displayed much higher activity than pure Co3O4. Among the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, Ru0.2-Co3O4 showed the best activity for N2O decomposition, which was 50%, 75% and 86% conversion of N2O at 300, 350 and 375°C, respectively. Meanwhile, the activities of theRu0.1-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4 catalysts were almost the same with each other. The results demonstrate that the conversion of N2O is improved over Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts compared with the Co3O4 catalyst. As shown in Table S1, the catalytic activity of Ru-based catalyst is different for the N2O decomposition under similar reaction conditions in the literatures [10,55]. Among these Ru-based catalysts, the temperature of 50% conversion to N2O for the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts was lower. Therefore, the interaction and support show important roles in the catalytic activity. Compared with Rh, Pt, Pd and Ir based catalysts, the catalytic activities of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) were higher in the almost same GHSV. The results indicate the catalytic activity for N2O decomposition can be improved after Ru doping to Co3O4. The N2O decomposition taking place over Co3O4 was considered as the first order [31]. On the base, the active energy (E a) and the rate constants (k) of the reaction over Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Co3O4 were calculated and listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that the k was 5.20×10−7, 1.50×10−6 and 4.89×10−6 m3 s−1 g−1 at 250, 300 and 350°C for Ru0.2-Co3O4, which is higher than the corresponding k of Co3O4 (1.55×10−7, 2.07×10−7 and 1.08×10−6 m3 s−1 g−1). Meanwhile, the active energy (E a) for Ru0.2-Co3O4 (54.9kJmol−1) was lower than that of Co3O4 (75.2kJmol−1), which indicates the active energy of N2O decomposition decreases obviously over Ru0.2-Co3O4. In the literatures [31,39,56], the active energy (E a) of Co3O4 were reported about 63.9, 73.9, 76, 92, 96, 103 and 107kJmol−1 which were prepared by the different precursors and k were 6.54×10−7, 1.77×10−6, 6.64×10−6 at 300, 350 and 400°C, respectively [31]. Compared with the results of literatures, our E a and k were similar and even smaller. The dependence of activity on time-on-stream was also explored over the Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Co3O4 catalysts at 400°C. As presented in Fig. 7 , the Co3O4 catalyst showed unstable activity that the initial activity (about 50%) was only maintained for 2h at 400°C; then, the N2O conversion decreased with time-on-stream to 25% after 30h. However, it was interesting that the N2O conversion (>80%) did not decrease until the reaction time was 30h over the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst, which indicates that the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst can maintain much higher activity and stability during the evaluated time. The stability of Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Co3O4 catalysts was also tested at 500°C depicted in Fig. S4. The similar results were obtained as those at 400°C. Overall, Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst exhibits much better activity and stability than Co3O4, which is attributed to its much higher structural stability. In our previous study [14], the deactivation reason of Co3O4 is related to its structural instability. However, as presented in Fig. S5, texture properties, reducibility, and surface species of the used Rux-Co3O4 did not change, which confirms that the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst has much higher structural stability. O2 is coexistent with N2O in tail gas of nitric acid production. Therefore, the activity was tested in the presence of O2 over the Co3O4 and Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalysts presented in Fig. 8 . The N2O conversion decreased quickly from 52% to about 10% for Co3O4 when O2 was added (Fig. 8). However, addition of O2 caused about 5% decrease in N2O conversion over the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst. The results suggest that the catalytic activity of Co3O4 was great influenced by O2, whereas, the Ru0.2-Co3O4 has a better O2 resistance for N2O decomposition. In tail gas of nitric acid production, water vapor is always coexistence with N2O. Therefore, the effect of water vapor on the N2O decomposition was also studied over the Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Co3O4 catalysts. Fig. 9 displays the N2O conversion in the presence of 500ppmN2O and 2.1% H2O. The N2O conversion decreased quickly from 52% to about 25% for Co3O4 when 2.1% H2O was added (Fig. 9b). By removing H2O, the conversion of N2O did not completely regain to 52%, only got to about 40%. However, the addition of 2.1% H2O did not cause the decrease of N2O conversion over the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 9a). The catalytic activity of Co3O4 was great influenced by H2O, whereas Ru0.2-Co3O4 has also a better H2O resistance for N2O decomposition. The XRD results show that there is no difference between Rux-Co3O4 and Co3O4 (Fig. 1), which indicates that the bulk structure of Co3O4 is unchanged after the addition of Ru. However, Rux-Co3O4 displays higher BET surface area and smaller particle dimensions than Co3O4. Raman spectra of the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts (Fig. S2) also exhibited slightly change compared with Co3O4. Thus, the results suggest an interaction between Co and Ru exists in the Rux-Co3O4 catalyst, which is further confirmed by the H2-TPR, O2-TPD and XPS results. The strong interaction causes a serial of changes including the intrinsic structure properties, surface species and reducibility that influence the activity of Rux-Co3O4 catalysts. The H2-TPR results (Fig. 3) indicate that the reducibility of Rux-Co3O4 is much higher than that of Co3O4. In addition, the amount and desorption ability of the surface chemisorbed oxygen increase for the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts in Fig. 4 (O2-TPD), suggesting the formation of more surface oxygen vacancy. The XPS of O1s also confirm the increase of the amount of surface adsorbed oxygen species on the oxygen vacancy sites for Rux-Co3O4 (Fig. 5c, Table 1). The Oα1/(Oα1 +Oα2 +Oβ) ratio is 0.44, 0.50 and 0.44 for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively, which is much higher than that of Co3O4 (0.38). Generally, the oxygen vacancies are considered as the adsorbed and active sites of the N2O molecular for the oxide catalysts [13,14,18,57,58]. It suggests that the number of active sites for Rux-Co3O4 is much more than that of Co3O4. Meanwhile, surface area, reducibility, desorption ability of the surface chemisorbed oxygen are all promoting factors for activity [31]. Thus, Rux-Co3O4 has much higher catalytic activity than Co3O4. Moreover, the XPS of Co2p results shows electron density of Co species increases because of Ru doping into Co3O4. From the XPS of Co2p (Fig. 5a, Table 1) results, the Co2+/Co3+ ratio for the Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4 is 1.45, 1.59 and 1.45 which is much higher than that of Co3O4 (1.00). CO adsorption results also confirm the presence of more Co2+ species on the surface of Ru0.2-Co3O4 than that of Co3O4 (Fig. S3). This demonstrates that the amount of Co2+ increases on the surface of catalyst after the addition of Ru into Co3O4. Generally, the decomposition of N2O over Co3O4 is considered as a redox process between Co2+ and Co3+ [27,33]. Co2+ interacts with N2O molecule, activate it effectively and form N2, which is recognized as active sites for N2O decomposition. Therefore, the more amount of Co2+ species on the surface of Rux-Co3O4 is in favor of the decomposition of N2O. The surface oxygen vacancy (Vo) and Co2+ are recognized as active sites for N2O decomposition [13,14,18,27,33,57,58]. The amount of surface oxygen vacancy is related to the surface Co2+ content. More surface oxygen vacancies can lead to the formation of more surface Co2+ content. The N2O molecule adsorbed on the active center Co2+ (Vo) to form the adsorbed N2O. Then, an electron transferred from Co2+ (Vo) to the adsorbed N2O molecule to form N2, Co3+ and O−. The oxygen vacancy was refilled by O− and it recombined into the gas-phase oxygen. Thus, the Co2+ and Vo was restored after O2 desorption, completing the catalytic cycle. Additionally, the chemical state of the Ru species on the surface of Rux-Co3O4 catalyst has an important effect on the catalytic activity of N2O decomposition. The XPS of Ru3d (Fig. 5b, Table 1) results indicate that the Ru3+/Ru4+ ratio is about 1.86, 2.57 and 1.44 for Ru0.1-Co3O4, Ru0.2-Co3O4 and Ru0.3-Co3O4, respectively. It suggests that there is a large amount of Ru3+ species on the surface of Rux-Co3O4. Benco’s report confirmed that Ru3+ species played a key role in N2O decomposition over Ru-based catalysts [11]. They used DFT to calculate the activation of N2O molecule over the Ru3+ and Ru4+ species (cationic oxo-particles (Ru-O2+, Ru-O+)). The Ru3+ species (Ru-O+ particle) was more active than the Ru4+ species (Ru-O2+ particle) for the activation of N2O molecule [11]. Thus, the Ru3+ species is one of the effective active sites for the decomposition of N2O over Rux-Co3O4. In summary, the surface properties of the catalysts are modified after Ru doping in Co3O4 due to the interaction between Ru and Co. Not only the amount of Co2+, Ru3+, oxygen vacancy and surface area increased on the surface of the catalyst, but also in the bulk phase the reducibility, desorption ability of the surface chemisorbed oxygen increased. The catalytic activity of Ru0.2-Co3O4 was the best for N2O decomposition among the Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts. This is attributed to the high reducibility, highest BET surface area, desorption ability of the surface chemisorbed oxygen, the amount of Co2+, Ru3+ and surface oxygen vacancy. 4 Conclusions A serial of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1–0.3) catalysts was synthesized by coprecipitation method. Various characterizations confirm the presence of a strong interaction between Co and Ru in Rux-Co3O4. It results in that they have much larger BET surface area and better structural stability compared with Co3O4. Additionally, the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, especial Ru0.2-Co3O4, show much higher activity and stability for N2O decomposition compared with Co3O4. Moreover, the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst also demonstrates excellent activity catalyst in the presence of 2.1% H2O. The characterization results indicate that Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst had the largest amount of surface Co2+, Ru3+ and surface oxygen species which are the key factors in its best catalytic activity of N2O decomposition among the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, which resulted from the strong interaction between the Co and Ru. coredata.dc:description: A serial of Rux-Co3O4 (x=0.1, 0.2 and 0.3) catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method and applied to the decomposition of N2O. They were characterized by the XRD, TEM, Raman, H2-TPR, XPS, O2-TPD and in situ DRIFTS. The results indicate that the strong interaction between Co and Ru exists in the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, which results in much larger BET surface area, better structural stability and more surface Co2+, Ru3+ and oxygen species compared with Co3O4. Additionally, the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts, especial Ru0.2-Co3O4, show much higher activity and stability than the Co3O4 catalyst due to the synergistic effect of Ru and Co3O4. Moreover, the Ru0.2-Co3O4 catalyst shows much stronger resistance against 2.1% H2O and 1.5% O2 in the feed than Co3O4.
coredata.dc:title: Interaction between Ru and Co3O4 for promoted catalytic decomposition of N2O over the Rux-Co3O4 catalysts
